Question: CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets.
CSS is used to describe how to display elements on a webpage created using HTML.
CSS cannot be reused for other websites.
Inline Style Sheets define styles within the style attribute of each HTML tag.
Embedding Style Sheets are defined within the <style> tag in the HTML document's <head> section.
External Style Sheets are stored in files with a .html extension.
The order of priority for applying styles in web pages (from highest to lowest) is: Inline style sheet, Embedding style sheet, External style sheet, Browser Default.
Selectors are not used to apply styles to elements in CSS.
Pseudo-elements are used to style a specific part of a selected element.
The `::first-line` pseudo-element selects the first character of a text.
The `::before` pseudo-element inserts content before the selected element.
Pseudo-classes are used to style elements based on their state.
The `:hover` pseudo-class applies styles when the mouse is over an element.
The `:first-child` pseudo-class styles the first element of a specific type within its parent.

Which property is used to set the background color of an element?
Which property is used to set the spacing between the content and the border of an element?

Which of these is NOT a generic font family?
